guide.introduction:
The Pop-Pop Steamboat in MAKE Volume 28 calls for using small tea candles for the engine's heat source, but I found that it didn't work very well. So I decided to make this small alcohol-burning lamp instead, and it significantly improved its performance.

In this project I will go over how to turn down two brass end-caps on a small lathe and then solder them onto a short length of copper pipe to make an alcohol-burning lamp to fuel your Pop-Pop boat. This project is for those who have basic skills with a lathe and metalworking. I will not go over dimensions, so you can come up with your own design. Have fun!
guide.introduction_rendered:
The Pop-Pop Steamboat in MAKE Volume 28 calls for using small tea candles for the engine's heat source, but I found that it didn't work very well. So I decided to make this small alcohol-burning lamp instead, and it significantly improved its performance.

In this project I will go over how to turn down two brass end-caps on a small lathe and then solder them onto a short length of copper pipe to make an alcohol-burning lamp to fuel your Pop-Pop boat. This project is for those who have basic skills with a lathe and metalworking. I will not go over dimensions, so you can come up with your own design. Have fun!

Relevant parts
  • Brass round stock
  • Straight copper pipe
  • Flexible copper tubing
  • Rubber O-ring
  • Short length of cotton string
  • Can of alcohol
Tools
  • Butane torch
  • Small Metal Lathe
  • Solder
  • Solder Flux
  • Tap and die set
  • Tube bender

parts.notes: that fits snugly inside 1/4" flexible copper tubing

lines.text: Using the lathe, turn down the brass round stock to create two end caps that fit in snugly in the copper pipe.
lines.text_raw: Using the lathe, turn down the brass round stock to create two end caps that fit in snugly in the copper pipe.

lines.text: One cap should have a 1/4" hole drilled through it for the copper tubing. The other cap will have a threaded hole for a brass threaded plug that you turn down. Make sure the threads match.
lines.text_raw: One cap should have a 1/4" hole drilled through it for the copper tubing. The other cap will have a threaded hole for a brass threaded plug that you turn down. Make sure the threads match.

lines.text: Put the O-ring on the brass plug.
lines.text_raw: Put the O-ring on the brass plug.

lines.text: Use the torch to soften the copper.
lines.text_raw: Use the torch to soften the copper.

lines.text: Then use the pliers to bend it into the correct shape, being careful not to crush the pipe.
lines.text_raw: Then use the pliers to bend it into the correct shape, being careful not to crush the pipe.

lines.text: Test fit it under the pop-pop boat engine to make sure it fits.
lines.text_raw: Test fit it under the pop-pop boat engine to make sure it fits.

lines.text: Make sure to apply plenty of flux to the inside of the pipe, then solder the non-threaded cap on.
lines.text_raw: Make sure to apply plenty of flux to the inside of the pipe, then solder the non-threaded cap on.

lines.text: After that, solder the bent copper tubing into the cap, making sure not to get any solder inside the tubing.
lines.text_raw: After that, solder the bent copper tubing into the cap, making sure not to get any solder inside the tubing.

lines.text: Next, solder the threaded cap onto the copper pipe. Don't forget the flux.
lines.text_raw: Next, solder the threaded cap onto the copper pipe. Don't forget the flux.

lines.text: After that, clean up any holes or rough solder with the torch.
lines.text_raw: After that, clean up any holes or rough solder with the torch.

lines.text: Cut a short length of cotton yarn and stuff it into the bent copper tubing.
lines.text_raw: Cut a short length of cotton yarn and stuff it into the bent copper tubing.

lines.text: I used a stiff metal wire to help get it all the way in. You want a little of the yarn sticking inside the copper tube; this will allow it to soak up the fuel.
lines.text_raw: I used a stiff metal wire to help get it all the way in. You want a little of the yarn sticking inside the copper tube; this will allow it to soak up the fuel.

lines.text: Use a wire wheel to roughly clean the burner.
lines.text_raw: Use a wire wheel to roughly clean the burner.

lines.text: After that, polish it up on the lathe with  fine-grit sandpaper.
lines.text_raw: After that, polish it up on the lathe with  fine-grit sandpaper.

lines.text: To run it, just fill it up with fuel, screw on the cap, and light the wick. That's it – you're done!
